Posts.Content: My husband is scheduled for surgery w/Dr. Tewari on 2/13. Was surprised to read you traveled from Boca bc that's where we live. Maybe it's a sign we made the right decision. I am the one who is doing the majority of the research and all of the scheduling and planning and I am overwhelmed with what I have learned in such a short period of time. And from what I am reading this is so easy with respect to what's to come. God Bless Everyone on this forum for their strength in helping others and the insights shared.

Posts.Title: It's Official - Zero Club

Posts.Content: Wifey, I think going through a health crisis makes us slow down and live life one day at a time. It's been 3 months since my husbands surgery and I find myself falling back into old habits. I have to remember to slow down and smell the roses sort to speak. Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Signature: Terry's numbers: PSA 3.2 4/2011 PSA. 7 10/2013 PSA. 5.3 11/2013 Free PSA 4. 11/2013 Age: 64 6' height, 201 lbs Gleason 7 (3+4) MRI, CT, Ultrasound all negative Biopsy 9/12 cores positive DaVinci surgery 2/13/14 Dr Ash Tewari Mt Sinai - NYC PSA 6 wks post op: non-detectable
Posts.Title: Insight into after surgery from a wife's perspective

Posts.Content: Husbands surgery was mid Feb this year. It's been just 3 months and life is normal. No incontinence at all. Our sex life is 99% normal. So much better than most of the posts I've read I realize how blessed we are (knock wood). I post this only to give hope to those who are anticipating the process. Even tho we both vowed to keep positive throughout the process it was extremely difficult, if not impossible, not to anticipate problems. So far so good.

Posts.Title: Marking a two year anniversary

Posts.Content: We r in Ny from Fl and my husbands surgery is tomorrow, nor'easter pax day. Met dr tewari on Monday after MRI and ct scan and results looked very good. In dr's words husband aced tests. Wish I had thought to ask dr based on the 9/12 positive cores, T2c stage and a70% positive core at the apex if surgery would be husbands most viable option. Any input/advice/opinions are appreciated. Also need to ask dr in light of expected blizzard if his "A" team will all be present and what happens if power outage during surgery. As if this isn't stressful enough! Thank you, Kat
Posts.Title: Husbands surgery tomorrow

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone for responding. Terry is in surgery now. The snow is insane here but we were lucky the blizzard conditions didn't begin until after we arrived at the hospital. Yes Mike, Dr T will give me the prelim pathology report while still in surgery. I am waiting for the nurse to call me up. Terry's numbers: PSA 3.2 4/2011 PSA. 7 10/2013 PSA. 5.3 11/2013 Free PSA 4. 11/2013 Age: 64 6' height, 201 lbs Gleason 7 (3+4) MRI, CT, Ultrasound all negative Biopsy 9/12 cores positive

Posts.Title: Husbands surgery tomorrow

Posts.Content: Surgery was 3 hrs and news was positive. Clean margins and nerves spared. He's been out of surgery now for 3 hrs and is very groggy still; somewhat coherent and in a lot of discomfort understandably. Is this grogginess the norm? Would appreciate hearing from others what their first 12-24 hrs were like. Thanks so much.

Posts.Title: Husbands surgery tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Barry, The help and support I have recd at this forum is priceless. You struck gold when you happened upon this site. I just wanted to wish you good luck and try to calm your stress a little bit by repeating to you what the doc told us and that is the cancer is not contagious through semen. As the wife I am surely hoping he's right. In the beginning of this unwelcome journey there was a mountain that We had no clue how to navigate through. But little by little, slowly but surely, my husband and I made it over the crest and you will too. Just remember to breathe. And ask lots of questions. Kat

Posts.Title: Open question to theszak

Posts.Content: For those of you like my husband and me who had never heard of Hope Lodge it is free lodging provided by the American Cancer Society for those of us who have to travel away from home for cancer treatment. We have been staying at the NYC Hope Lodge and I can't say enough good about what a blessing this has been. They are 31 located nationwide. Reservations are made through referral by your doctor and need to be started as soon as you know your dates. We were incredibly fortunate and want to share this info. http://www.cancer.org/treatment/supp...ces/hopelodge/
Posts.Title: Hope Lodge

Posts.Content: Very interesting. My husband also had low Vit D and was put on Vit D supplements for a few years prior to his PSA rise/aggressive cancer.

Posts.Content: My husbands first post op PSA test was at 6 wks. Undetectable at tha time (knock on wood) Next one is 3 months later which is actually coming up at the end of the month. I think a lot depends on the pathology and the doctor. Good luck Wolfgang.

Posts.Title: How long after prostatectomy one may expect PSA test results to be accurate?

Posts.Content: Terry's first PSA at 6 wks was undetectable. 2nd follow up test is Monday. I know bike riding, sex etc could skew results when there was still a prostate but was wondering if there were any post RP factors that could now influence results. I don't think the Cowpers were removed . . . I'm just saying. Thanks as always. Kat

Posts.Title: Post op PSA

Posts.Content: I'm the member but the following is my husband's blog: Thursday, Day of surgery 2/13: 3 1/2 hr robotic prostatectomy: weak, bloated w/gas, abdominal pain, catheter discomfort. Approx 3hrs post surgery nurse got me up to walk. Got from hospital room window to the hallway door. Felt dizzy and nauseous. Nurse said "breathe". Best advice. In thru nose out thru mouth. At midnight couldn't sleep. Elected for two Percocet and finally fell asleep. Passed gas and stained bed pad. Embarrassing but felt great. 4am took first of many laps around the nurse's station. Next day, Friday: discharged 2pm with 2 Percocet for anticipated pain getting in and out of cab. Abdominal pain was primary pain, catheter was second. 2nd day post op, Saturday: Bowels began to function as gas and diarrhea. Felt like a king. Finally allowed to eat solid food. Walked hallways at Hope Lodge and ventured out to the city streets 4 doors down to deli for first taste of solid food since Tuesday. 3rd day post op Sunday: abdominal pain subsiding. Only using Advil. Walking hallways and city streets. Walking helped reduced abdominal pain, increase blood flow and stronger bm's. Took well deserved shower. 4th day post op Monday: BM's more structured. Experienced soft erection during the night 3/10. Walking morning and afternoon. 5th day post op Tuesday: BM's solidified followed by blood in urine (cranberry colored) runs clear between BM's. This is common as per doc. Frame of mind very strong. Experienced moderate erection 6/10. Abdominal discomfort minimal and stomach swelling significantly reduced. Longer walks twice daily. 6th day post op Wednesday: continue feeling stronger. Solid BM's. Woke up with stronger erection. Presently 9th day post op (Saturday). Minimal stomach swelling, no Advil needed since 5th day post op. Continue to drink copious amounts of liquids: water, coconut water, decaf tea & coffee. Twice daily walks are longer in distance, pace and duration. My diet is simple as to not tax my digestive tract. Oatmeal, fruit, eggs, pasta, vegetables, salad, soup and a daily sweet or two. No meat. Sleep is restful. Urine is clear even after BM. The catheter is not an issue and I continue to be awakened out of my sleep with a welcomed feeling of bliss knowing that my cancer is gone and I can still function as a man for my loving wife of 33 years. I am scheduled to meet with Dr. Tewari on Monday 2/24 for the removal of the cathetar and pathology reports. Please feel free to ask anything. Hope this helps.
